title: 107_hr2009
content: The Act titled "PROTECTION Act" is also known as the "Providing Reliable Officers, Technology, Education, Community Prosecutors, and Training In Our Neighborhoods Act of 2001". It aims to implement the Providing Reliable Officers, Technology, Education, Community Prosecutors, and Training in Our Neighborhood Initiative. The COPS Program under the PROTECTION Act of 2001 is amended to increase police and prosecutor presence, enhance law enforcement access to new technologies, and provide grants for hiring and redeployment of law enforcement officers for community policing efforts. The COPS Program under the PROTECTION Act of 2001 is amended to promote higher education among in-service State and local law enforcement officers by reimbursing them for education costs and limiting overtime grants to 25 percent of available funds. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to limit the funds available for grants in any fiscal year. Additionally, grant projects now include specialized integrity and ethics training for law enforcement officers, as well as involvement of school officials and religiously-affiliated organizations. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to establish school-based partnerships between law enforcement agencies and school systems, using school resource officers to combat crime, gang activity, firearms incidents, alcohol and drug-related issues. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include innovative programs like the TRIAD program, bringing together law enforcement and elderly residents to address public safety concerns. Technical assistance allows the Attorney General to use up to 5 percent of funds for various purposes. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include innovative programs like the TRIAD program, bringing together law enforcement and elderly residents to address public safety concerns. Funds appropriated for technical assistance and training to various entities are specified, with amendments regarding the Attorney General's role and the inclusion of regional community policing institutes and representatives of police labor and management organizations. Additionally, technology and prosecution programs are addressed in Section 1701 of title I. Section 1701 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include a Law Enforcement Technology Program that allows grants to be used for improving police communications and access to crime-solving technologies. The Law Enforcement Technology Program aims to enhance access to crime-solving technologies like DNA analysis and promote comprehensive crime analysis through techniques such as crime mapping. Grants can also support community-based prosecution programs that complement local community policing efforts. Funds under this subsection can be used to hire additional prosecutors for community prosecution programs, redeploy existing prosecutors, and establish programs to assist local prosecutors. The text chunk discusses the allocation of funds for grants to assist local prosecutors in addressing priority crime problems in communities with tailored solutions. At least 75 percent of the funds will be reserved for specific grants, with a portion designated for units of local government with a population of less than 50,000. Additionally, the Attorney General may use up to 50 percent of the funds for retention grants under certain conditions. The curr_chunk discusses the allocation of funds for grants targeted for retention of police officers in good standing, with preference for those facing financial hardship or severe budget constraints. Definitions for career law enforcement officer and school resource officer are also provided. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions for law enforcement liaisons and training students in conflict resolution and crime awareness. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions for law enforcement liaisons to work with school administrators, community members, and emergency personnel in creating a school violence prevention plan and documenting firearms found on school property. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions for law enforcement liaisons to work with school administrators, community members, and emergency personnel in creating a school violence prevention plan, documenting firearms and explosives found on school property, and assisting with the preparation of the Department of Education's Annual Report on State Implementation of the Gun-Free Schools Act. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to authorize appropriations for school violence prevention, with specific funding amounts allocated for fiscal years 2002 to 2007. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase the hiring funds allocation from 3 percent to 5 percent and make adjustments to the allocation process based on demand from law enforcement agencies in high population areas. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase hiring funds allocation to 5 percent, with adjustments for demand from law enforcement agencies in high population areas. $600,000,000 is allocated for grants for areas with populations exceeding 150,000, and $350,000,000 for grants specified in section 1701(e) for areas with populations less than 150,000. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allocate $200,000,000 for grants specified in section 1701(f).
